title: U.S. Hospitals Face Major Challenges as Coronavirus Spreads
summary: Executives are scrambling for beds and space to put patients if severe cases spike, searching for medical supplies and trying to ensure there are enough doctors and nurses. William Olson, the chief of operations for eight Oregon hospitals, grew worried when he was shown a heat map of coronavirus cases and flulike symptoms among patients across seven Western states.

title: Facts (and Myths) About Boosting Your Immune System
summary: It's crucial to stay healthy as the threat of coronavirus spreads. Here are the best strategies.. As the new coronavirus continues to spread across the country, having an optimally functioning immune system is more important than ever.

title: How to Work From Home: A Checklist of the Essentials
summary: For starters, make sure your internet speed is up to the task, and minimize distractions. What's the best way to work effectively from home? That has suddenly become an urgent question as employers around the world tell staffers to work remotely in an effort to stem the spread of the new coronavirus.

title: How to Keep Your Home Free of Coronavirus Germs
summary: Tips include cleaning with EPA-approved disinfectants and running dishwashers on sanitize cycle if possible. For many people, staying safe from the new coronavirus means staying home. But infectious germs can live in your house, too.

title: As Virus Spreads, Drugmakers Are On the Case
summary: Numerous projects are under way to find cures or treatments-but don't expect an answer anytime soon. Dozens of drugmakers are scrambling to develop vaccines that could prevent people from contracting the new coronavirus, or therapies to treat people infected with the respiratory disease it causes.

title: How One Family Is Dealing With Life, Disrupted
summary: In Hong Kong, they face closed schools and facilities, shortages of some necessities-and a small apartment. HONG KONG-I never realized how much I enjoyed sending my children off to school and going to work in the mornings until I could no longer do either.

title: Broadcom Withdraws Annual Financial Guidance Over Coronavirus Uncertainty
summary: Chip maker expects revenue of about $5.7 billion in the current quarter, below analysts' projection. Chip maker Broadcom Inc. on Thursday pulled its financial projections for the year, citing uncertainty around the coronavirus pandemic, and said it would push debt payments to the second half of the year or earlier if conditions improve.

title: America's Self-Shutdown
summary: The public has made 'social distancing' de facto national policy.. For all the foreboding about the novel coronavirus-foreboding that is justified-it is heartening to see the American people responding in ways reminiscent of the frontier spirit. Most people are doing what they have to do to survive a clear and immediate threat to their lives and communities.

title: Bernie's Offer Sheet
summary: The defeated candidate dictates his terms of support to Biden.. After multiple primary defeats, Bernie Sanders seems to know he can't win the Democratic nomination, but he isn't going away. In a speech Wednesday, Mr. Sanders claimed he "has won the ideological debate" but is "losing the debate over electability." Then he listed questions he intends to ask Joe Biden in their televised debate Sunday, including:

title: Companies Weigh Currency-Hedging Strategies Amid Coronavirus Market Turmoil
summary: The pandemic has put finance chiefs' liquidity plans to the test. Finance chiefs are reviewing currency-hedging strategies to manage liquidity as widespread volatility spurred by the coronavirus pandemic spills over into foreign-exchange markets.

title: The Fed's Liquidity Cavalry
summary: The central bank rides to the rescue of the Treasury market but in confusing fashion.. The good news Thursday-and there was some-is that the Federal Reserve rode to the liquidity rescue of financial markets. The bad news is that equity markets rallied only briefly and then kept falling to close down a harrowing 10%. Flooding the Treasury markets with cash was still the right Fed call, though in this evolving panic the Fed ought to explain better what it's doing and why.

title: Europe's Viral Recession
summary: Covid-19 would be less threatening if economies had been healthier.. European leaders are struggling to cope with the health consequences of Covid-19, and now the next struggle is coming into view-the economy. The pandemic is all but certain to tip large parts of Europe into recession, and no leader has a good response.

title: 'Don't Panic' Is Rotten Advice
summary: A grave crisis calls for reason and realism, not 'an abundance of caution.'. This coronavirus is new to our species-it is "novel." It spreads more easily than the flu-"exponentially," as we now say-and is estimated to be at least 10 times as lethal.

title: Bank of Canada to Expand Liquidity Operations
summary: Central bank to broaden bond buyback program and add new term-repo operations. OTTAWA-The Bank of Canada on Thursday said it was broadening its programs aimed at ensuring there is enough cash in the country's financial system, in the latest indication of deteriorating conditions in Canada stemming from the coronavirus pandemic and the sharp pullback in crude-oil prices.

title: Judge Orders Chelsea Manning Released From Jail
summary: She has been held for refusing to testify before a grand jury investigating Julian Assange. WASHINGTON-Chelsea Manning, the former U.S. Army intelligence analyst convicted of leaking government secrets to WikiLeaks, must be released from a jail where she has been held for refusing to testify before a grand jury investigating its founder, Julian Assange, a federal judge said.

title: Whitney MacMillan Transformed Cargill Into a Global Food Giant
summary: CEO expanded firm with mills and plants in South America, Europe and Asia. Whitney MacMillan, relying on pragmatism and endless curiosity about how the world feeds itself, transformed Cargill Inc. from a North American grain trader into a global food colossus.

title: 'The World Beneath Their Feet' Review: Himalayan Heroes
summary: Crowds thronged the streets of London to see the new queen when news broke out: British climbers had become the ﬁrst to scale Mount Everest.. Enormous crowds of people thronged the sidewalks of London on June 2, 1953, as they waited for the coronation procession of Queen Elizabeth II. Many had stood in the rain overnight to secure the best vantage points. Then, at a few minutes before 8 a.m.-hours before anyone would catch their first glimpse of the new monarch-thrilling news electrified the multitude: British mountaineers had become the first to climb the 29,029-foot Mount Everest. People "cheered and danced," Scott Ellsworth tells us in "The World Beneath Their Feet." The triumphant finale to a 30-year quest to summit the world's tallest mountain delivered "a glorious, unforgettable moment," a "crowning touch" to the young queen's ascension.

title: It May Not Be the Virus That Kills Me
summary: Many lives depend on the medical supply chain, which Covid-19 will severely test.. With each passing day, the coronavirus pandemic reveals that many of our lives hang by a thin fiber-optic thread that can snap at any time. As more people are quarantined and businesses grind to a halt, supply chains will break down. While this will have negative economic consequences for all, for many of us it will be a matter of life and death.

title: The IRS Proves the Left's Favorite Economists Wrong
summary: New data contradict Saez and Zucman's celebrated claim that the rich pay lower rates than the poor.. 'The Rich Really Do Pay Lower Taxes Than You" read a headline in the New York Times last fall. This astounding claim, presented in the media as fact and evidence of inequities baked into President Trump's 2017 tax cut, came from two economists at the University of California, Berkeley. Emmanuel Saez and Gabriel Zucman asserted that 2018 was the first year in U.S. history that the average tax rate on the 400 wealthiest income earners dipped below the rates paid by the lower-middle class and poor.

title: Notable & Quotable: Sanders Has Already Won
summary: 'Biden and Sanders actually agree on far more than they disagree.'. Bill Press, writing for the Hill, March 10:

title: Broadway Going Dark Could Mean Losses Above $100 Million
summary: Cultural institutions say shutdowns are necessary to ensure the safety of the public and their staff. With Broadway and New York City's broader cultural scene coming to a coronavirus-prompted close on Thursday, industry professionals are tallying the potential financial impact.

title: Slack Isn't Zooming Yet
summary: Collaboration-software upstart has benefited from work-from-home interest, but its latest outlook comes up short. The coronavirus pandemic may be good for Slack Technologies , but it isn't in the numbers yet.

title: Working Remotely Requires Cultural Change, Executives Say
summary: CEO of totally remote startup GitLab says he is getting questions from customers on how to establish effective work-from-home programs. The coronavirus pandemic has shined the spotlight on remote work and collaboration technologies, as businesses world-wide encourage staff to work from home in an effort to reduce risk. But now that the laptops have been procured and the Zoom video-collaboration software downloaded, what's next?

title: Sports TV Networks Take a Hit as Major Leagues Suspend Operations Over Coronavirus
summary: Networks face lost ad revenue and pressure from distributors as NBA sports-rights payments loom. Sports TV networks are facing a big problem: They have virtually no games to put on the air.

title: Tech Companies See Mixed Impact From Coronavirus
summary: Publishing software provider Adobe cites impact on corporate spending, particularly in areas hit by the pandemic. The spreading coronavirus is shaping up to deliver mixed fortunes for tech companies.

title: Stocks Plunge 10% in Dow's Worst Day Since 1987
summary: Benchmarks slide as S&P, Nasdaq join Dow in bear-market territory. U.S. stocks plunged Thursday in their worst day since the 1987 crash. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 10%, and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq tumbled nearly as much to join the Dow in a bear market.

title: France's Macron Urges Global Effort to Contain Coronavirus
summary: French president also announces nationwide school closure, urges elderly to stay home. PARIS-French President Emmanuel Macron delivered a national address that called for international cooperation in the fight against the new coronavirus, drawing contrast with President Trump's announcement from the Oval Office that he was ordering a near-blanket travel ban to the U.S. for most Europeans.

title: Derby's Take: Super Aggressive Fed Actions May Help Smooth Unsettled Bond Market
summary: Resume Subscription. The New York Fed's shock announcement Thursday that it is willing to offer up to $1.5 trillion in fresh short-term loans to big banks may have captured the most attention simply for the radical size of the number.

title: SEC Votes to Ease Audit Requirements for Smaller Companies
summary: Supporters say move will aid investment; critics see risks for financial standards. WASHINGTON-Hundreds of small, publicly traded companies, including biotechnology firms, will see their audit requirements eased under a rule approved by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: A Potential Nightmare for the Magic Kingdom
summary: Disney's theme parks are its biggest business-and the one most at risk from coronavirus pandemic. Magical thinking can't insulate the most magical place on Earth. Disney investors now face a costly and upsetting development.

title: Muni Bonds Plummet as Few Markets Are Immune From Selloff
summary: The S&P Municipal Bond Index posts its biggest one-day drop in more than a decade. Municipal-bond prices plunged to record lows Thursday amid a selloff in stocks and other assets, as investors dumped even gold-plated debt.

title: Dorothy, We Aren't in 'Mediocristan' Any More
summary: Thursday's market crash will go down in history books, but it is less of an outlier than many believe. Thursday's stock-market meltdown was, putting it mildly, unusual. A 10% drop in the Dow Jones Industrial Average has only occurred a handful of times, mostly during the white-knuckle panics of 1929 and 2008. It was the worst in percentage terms since the record one-day decline in October 1987.

title: Germany Labels Part of Opposition Party an Extreme-Right Group
summary: Intelligence agency's move caps yearlong probe, allows surveillance of some members of AfD party. BERLIN-Germany's domestic intelligence agency said on Thursday that it would put a group within the nativist AfD opposition party under surveillance as an extremist organization amid rising concern about growing far-right violence in the country.

title: Judge Nixes New York Law Setting Up Public Campaign-Finance System
summary: Justice wrote that move was an 'improper and unconstitutional delegation of legislative authority'. A state judge on Thursday invalidated New York state's new system of public campaign financing, which was set to take effect after the 2022 elections.

title: Traders Caught in Market Downdraft Are Forced to Unwind Leveraged Strategies
summary: Bond and stock prices' sharp dual decline unnerved traders wary of margin calls, debt limits. Treasury prices extended their declines Thursday while U.S. stock indexes suffered their worst losses since 1987-an unusual dual downturn that raised concerns that the Wall Street rout is entering a painful new stage: The forced unwind of a number of popular trading strategies, some of which involve leverage, or borrowed money.

title: Economists See Rising Risks of Recession World-Wide
summary: Overall economic impact of coronavirus will depend on how quickly authorities can bring it under control. The U.S. and world economies look increasingly likely to slip into recession as expanding swaths of commerce shut down and the Dow Jones Industrial Average suffered its worst day since 1987 amid the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Gap Promotes Old Navy Finance Chief to CFO of Company
summary: Move is part of a larger corporate reshuffling at the clothing retailer. Gap Inc. said the finance chief of its Old Navy brand will be promoted to CFO of the whole company.

title: Senate Fails to Approve Renewal of Domestic-Surveillance Powers
summary: Domestic spying tools now set to expire in three days; two GOP senators clash on Senate floor. WASHINGTON-A set of domestic spying tools appeared likely to expire in three days after the Senate failed to approve legislation that would have renewed them amid doubts from President Trump that lawmakers had done enough to overhaul a surveillance system he has condemned.

title: Everything Is Going Wrong All at Once for U.S. Banks
summary: Epidemic triggers risks from low interest rates, slow loan growth and sliding stock and energy prices. Add together some of the biggest challenges U.S. banks weathered in the dozen years since the financial crisis, and you get an idea of how bad the coronavirus epidemic could be for them.

title: Bestselling Books Week Ended March 7
summary: With data from NPD BookScan.

title: Concert Promoters Suspend Shows Around the World
summary: The rapid spread of coronavirus is hitting just before the start of critical summer season. The concert industry is suspending all major shows globally through the end of the month as it contends with the rapid spread of the novel coronavirus.

title: GE Proposes Keeping KPMG as External Auditor
summary: Larry Culp, General Electric's chief executive, got 2019 compensation valued at $24.6 million. General Electric Co. will keep KPMG LLP as its auditor for another year, extending a relationship that dates back more than a century and has been tested recently by accounting problems.

title: Europe Criticizes U.S. Travel Ban; Airlines Rush to Respond
summary: Restrictions are a hit to already reeling airline industry. LONDON-Governments, airlines and travelers scrambled to react to the announcement of a near-blanket travel ban to the U.S. for most Europeans.

title: U.S. Virus Testing System Is Failing, Fauci Tells Congress
summary: Top infectious-disease doctor cites patients' requirement to get doctor's permission as roadblock. WASHINGTON-The federal government's top infectious-disease doctor said the nation's system for disease testing has failed during the coronavirus outbreak because people typically need a doctor's permission to be tested.

title: Even Gold Takes a Beating as Broad Market Rout Intensifies
summary: Metal falls sharply as some investors are being forced to raise cash to make up for losses from stocks. Gold prices fell sharply Thursday, a worrisome development for some analysts who are concerned that investors are being forced to sell many assets to raise cash.

title: Oracle Tees Up Another $15 Billion in Buybacks
summary: The enterprise-software provider posted $9.79 billion in quarterly revenue, beating forecasts. Oracle Corp. said it would beef up its stock buyback program, a move that comes as the business software company's shares are battered by the coronavirus and broader economic uncertainty.

title: FASB Issues More Relief to Help Companies With Libor Transition
summary: The latest guidance allows businesses to preserve hedge accounting when modifying financial contracts. The Financial Accounting Standards Board on Thursday issued additional optional relief to companies transitioning away from the London interbank offered rate.

title: Coronavirus Whipsaws Treasury Yields, Investors Sell Corporate Bonds
summary: The gap between what dealers are willing to pay for Treasurys, and sell them for, has increased. The coronavirus crisis continued to send shock waves through debt markets, prompting sharp swings in Treasury yields and more selling in corporate bonds.

title: Fed to Inject $1.5 Trillion in Bid to Prevent 'Unusual Disruptions' in Markets
summary: Move designed to prevent ominous trading conditions stemming from the coronavirus outbreak. The Federal Reserve said it would make vast sums of short-term loans available on Wall Street and purchase Treasury securities in a coronavirus-related response aimed at preventing ominous trading conditions from creating a sharper economic contraction.

title: Tupperware Brands Names New CEO as Business Looks for Traction
summary: Miguel Fernandez is charged with modernizing the sales model. Tupperware Brands Corp. appointed a new chief executive with a background in direct selling, charging him with reinvigorating the company's performance as it struggles to reach consumers who have moved away from buying kitchenware at home parties.

title: As Recession Looms, Priority Is Lessening Severity, Easing Financial Stress
summary: Central banks, Congress have tools to soften shocks-but not much time. In the last week the coronavirus shock has sharply raised the probability that the U.S., and the world at large, will suffer a recession. The main challenge for the world now is limiting its severity and preventing a health crisis from becoming a financial crisis.

title: U.S. Movie Theaters See Temporary Closures as Strong Possibility
summary: Sequels to 'Fast & Furious,' 'Quiet Place' were postponed Thursday. U.S. movie theaters are increasingly likely to shut down temporarily, according to a person familiar with the matter, amid growing concerns related to the novel coronavirus pandemic.

title: New York City Shuts Two Public Schools Over Coronavirus Case
summary: Laboratory School of Finance and Technology and South Bronx Preparatory to be closed for at least 24 hours. Two New York City public schools that share a building were closed Thursday after a student tested positive for the novel coronavirus, city officials said.

title: White House Evaluates Trump Exposure to Coronavirus
summary: Brazilian official who recently met with president has tested positive for Covid-19; Congress closes U.S. Capitol to public. WASHINGTON-Concerns about the possibility that President Trump has been exposed to coronavirus mounted on Thursday after a Brazilian official who met with the president last weekend tested positive for the virus.

title: 'Panic': That Wave of Anxiety Is Named After a Partying Greek God
summary: The term comes from a half-goat deity known for playing pipes-and occasionally letting out terrifying screams.. "Unfortunately, you're going to see more deaths," Surgeon General Dr. Jerome Adams said on CNN last Sunday, speaking about the spread of the novel coronavirus in the U.S. "But that doesn't mean we should panic."

title: 'The Hunt': Stalking Satire
summary: Liberal elites pursue right-wingers in a sly gorefest.. 'The Hunt" occupies a special place in the chockablock landscape of movie junk. This gleeful, gross-out gorefest looks as tacky and violent as its trackdown plot would suggest, and lives up to certain parts of its bad reputation. It is also funny, genuinely topical, extremely shrewd and, heaven help us, slyly wise. I liked it quite a lot.

title: 'Never Rarely Sometimes Always': Life or Death in Few Words
summary: Two young women from rural Pennsylvania travel to New York to terminate an unexpected pregnancy.. What we see in a work of art depends on how we look at it. That's certainly true of Eliza Hittman's "Never Rarely Sometimes Always." The subject is explosive-a pregnant 17-year-old, Autumn (Sidney Flanigan), travels with her cousin and best friend Skylar (Talia Ryder) from rural Pennsylvania to New York City in search of a safe abortion. And the filmmaker's point of view is quietly but passionately pro-choice. Still, this tough-minded, forthright and exquisitely tender film transcends polemics. It's the odyssey of a lost child in poorly charted territory.

title: Cuomo Warns New York Hospitals of Coronavirus Surge
summary: Facilities may need to stop all elective surgeries, he warns. New York hospitals may need to halt all elective surgeries and recall former doctors and nurses to handle a surge in novel coronavirus patients, Gov. Andrew Cuomo said Thursday.

title: Juul Co-Founder to Step Down From Board
summary: James Monsees leaves e-cigarette maker as it faces increasing financial and regulatory pressures arising from increase in teen vaping. A co-founder of controversial e-cigarette maker Juul Labs Inc. is stepping down from its board, the company said Thursday.

title: 'The Plot Against America' Review: Fictional History for a Frictional Present
summary: Philip Roth's fable about an anti-Semitic President Charles Lindbergh and his persecution of American Jews is retooled to touch on contemporary concerns.. Among last year's nominees for the short-documentary Oscar was Marshall Curry's "A Night at the Garden," about a German-American Bund rally-replete with swastikas and sieg heils-that took place in a packed-to-the-rafters Madison Square Garden in 1939. Mr. Curry made a taut, dramatic seven-minute film out of footage he'd discovered. But the most remarkable thing for many was discovering that the event had taken place at all.

title: 'Little Fires Everywhere' Review: Bio-Rights Spark Controversy
summary: The adaptation of Celeste Ng's novel is a complicated examination of class, race and parenthood.. Based on Celeste Ng's bestselling novel of 2017, "Little Fires Everywhere" is Hulu's response to HBO's popular "Big Little Lies," another star-powered soap opera with a literary pedigree, feminist leanings and Reese Witherspoon. A story about class and race that strenuously avoids saying "class" or "race," the adapted "Little Fires Everywhere" does contain enough bad behavior to make it a guilty pleasure. Even if guilt is the principal ingredient that the show is missing, and to a fatal degree.

title: Morningstar: Why Is Everyone So Worried?
summary: The mutual-fund research firm thinks we are overreacting to coronavirus but projects for large number of deaths. In any bear market, there are a handful of financial pundits who cover themselves in glory and many more who wish they could delete the internet. And then there's Morningstar .

title: Bitcoin Falls Sharply as Crypto Gets Caught in Global Selloff
summary: Thursday's moves were exacerbated by the fact that crypto markets don't have internal controls to slow selloffs. The price of bitcoin fell sharply Thursday, at one point losing more than 20% in less than an hour, a steep drop even for the notoriously volatile asset.

title: Can Women Really Look Like Jennifer Lopez at 50?
summary: The glorification of super-fit 50-something stars including J. Lo and Jennifer Aniston, as well as a surge in antiaging tech, are putting a formerly sidelined age squarely in the spotlight. But the jury is out on whether 'the new 50' is inspirational or unachievable. QUESTION FOR you, me and every other woman who has blown out 50-plus candles on recent birthday cakes: Did we honestly think Jennifer Lopez would look anything but spectacular when she reached our age? This is a former "Fly Girl" who just delivered an entirely plausible performance as a stripper in 2019's "Hustlers," then imported an iteration of her trusty pole to the 2020 Super Bowl half-time show and, Spandex-clad, stunned viewers with her gyrations. You don't do either of those things at ages 49 and 50, respectively, without a mammoth amount of prep, and, in Ms. Lopez's case, years of herculean determination to stay not just youthful, but stripper-hot. While Ms. Lopez might be an outlier, she's certainly not the only Hollywood woman redefining what the 50s can look like. Catherine Zeta-Jones (50), Jennifer Aniston (51), Salma Hayek (53) and Halle Berry (53) are all also driving the conversation around shifting beauty standards.

title: College Students' Dispersal Over Virus Concern Expected to Snarl Census
summary: Students who live at their schools should be counted there, not at their parents' homes, even if they are home on a vacation or break, according to the Census Bureau. The sudden dispersal of college students across the U.S. as schools seek to limit the spread of the novel coronavirus could complicate the Census Bureau's plan to count students at their school addresses.

title: U.S. Sanctions Another Rosneft Trading Subsidiary
summary: Washington is seeking to pressure Russian oil power as it moves more deeply into Venezuela's oil industry. WASHINGTON-The Trump administration added another subsidiary of Russian state oil giant Rosneft to its financial blacklist for allegedly helping Venezuela sell its oil in violation of U.S. sanctions.

title: Some Favor New California Election Process
summary: I am not a fan of California's politicians' often nutty ideas and free-spending ways, but the new voter system worked better than the old one.. Regarding your editorial "California Steals Its Own Election" (March 7): I am not a fan of California's politicians' often nutty ideas and free-spending ways, but the new voter system worked better than the old one, in my opinion. It allowed me to easily vote before Super Tuesday at a convenient location of my choice. The staff was knowledgeable and helpful. I voted on Monday and was in and out in five minutes. I purposely chose a site that had been up and running for several days, as I have worked on software implementations and did not want to use the "beta" sites that had only been running a day or two.

title: Private Sector's Accommodation of Religion
summary: Nathan Lewin laments the fact that private industry doesn't provide the same religious liberty that the public sector does.. Nathan Lewin points out in "The Justices Punt on Religious Liberty" (Houses of Worship, March 6) that he has worked as an attorney in the public sector. He states that Justice John Harlan, Attorney General Ramsey Clark, Judge Richard Williams and the Supreme Court all gave him time off so could attend to his religious obligations. Consequently his reference about how an employer should respond to religious liberty is quite a bit skewed.

title: Many Are Happy With Bike Trails in the Neighborhood
summary: People walking, running or biking on a linear park are no more "wandering across their [private landowners'] properties" than if they were on the street side of their homes.. I am surprised to read that Steven Malanga lumps in converting old rail lines with other eminent-domain cases ("We're From the Government and We're Here to Build a Bike Path," Cross Country, Feb. 15). Let me just say that people walking, running or biking on a linear park are no more "wandering across their [private landowners'] properties" than if they were on the street side of their homes.

title: Federal Reserve Should Let The Market Correct Itself
summary: The sharp and steep decline in equity prices last week is partially due to the fact that the Fed's easy money policy has separated finance from the economy.. In "The Fed Can't Wait to Respond to the Coronavirus" (op-ed, Feb. 27), Kevin Warsh notes that: "If the Fed had normalized policy in the decadelong recovery, it would be far better situated . . . to take necessary action now" to confront a new risk, the coronavirus. But at the same time he is making the wrong policy recommendation. The recent sharp and steep decline in equity prices is partially due to the fact that the Federal Reserve's easy-money policy has separated finance from the economy. Missteps in policy decisions have elevated equity prices to record levels versus nominal GDP, and it would be prudent to let the rebalancing occur naturally. Yet in this highly political world the odds of that happening seem very low.

title: Oil Markets Point to a Lasting Glut of Crude
summary: A closely watched market indicator shows supply is expected to dwarf demand in the coming months. Energy markets are flashing a warning: The world is swimming in crude oil, and the glut won't drain away any time soon.

title: U.S. Travel Ban Is Expected to Snarl Trans-Atlantic Airfreight
summary: Much of the air cargo between U.S. and Europe is transported on passenger planes. The U.S. 30-day ban on some travel from Europe could have a significant impact on the movement of trans-Atlantic cargo flown in the bellies of passenger planes, driving up shipping rates and crimping airfreight capacity, industry executives said.

title: Is There a Flu Silver Lining in the Covid-19 Response?
summary: Could it be that the well-published recommended precautions resulting from fear of contracting Covid-19 virus might actually reduce cases of ordinary flu?. Holman Jenkins, Jr. notes that there are upward of 300,000 human deaths globally from ordinary flu every year ("A Chinese Mystery and Covid-19's Economic Puzzle," Business World, March 7).

title: Fed Repos Surge After It Expands Offerings, $361.5 Billion Now Outstanding
summary: New repo operations totaled $276.5 billion amid increased demand from banks. In the wake of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York's shock announcement that it would provide up to $1.5 trillion in new temporary liquidity, the outstanding amount of money lent to major banks and financial firms surged to its highest level on Thursday since operations restarted in September.

title: U.S. Soccer President Apologizes After U.S. Women Protest Court Filing
summary: Carlos Cordeiro addressed the filing's language after sponsor criticism and players turning jerseys inside-out. U.S. Soccer Federation president Carlos Cordeiro apologized Wednesday night in the wake of sponsor backlash to a controversial federation court filing and a public protest by the U.S. women's soccer team suing it for pay discrimination.

title: ECB Steps Up Stimulus, but Doesn't Cut Rates
summary: Remarks by European Central Bank President Christine Lagarde suggest she is not inclined to match the boldness of her predecessor, Mario Draghi. FRANKFURT-European Central Bank President Christine Lagarde unveiled a modest stimulus package to shield the region's economy from the fast-spreading coronavirus, but the action raised concerns the central bank may be unwilling or unable to move forcefully against a shock that has ricocheted through Europe.

title: Taiwan and the Virus
summary: A hopeful example in public health.. Responding to the coronavirus is not cheap. Caitlin Ostroff, Joanne Chiu and Caitlin McCabe report in the Journal:

title: A Painter Between Countries
summary: James Tissot was a star in the art worlds of late 19th-century London and Paris.. By the age of 35, Jacques Tissot was one of the most sought-after society portraitists in Paris. But in 1871, after the defeat of France in its war against Prussia and the fall of the revolutionary Paris Commune, he moved to London, where he remade himself as James Tissot, a narrative painter in the Victorian style. The new exhibition "James Tissot, Ambiguously Modern," opening at Paris's Musée D'Orsay on March 24, aims to bring both halves of his career together. "Most of the art historians who have studied Tissot's work over the last few years have been British, whose focus has been almost entirely on the Victorian period of the artist when he was in London," says Marine Kisiel, one of the show's curators. "We wanted to shift this perspective by demonstrating that Tissot had a long career in different stages."

title: Behind the Scenes of U.S. Coronavirus Economic Policy-Making
summary: Treasury Secretary Mnuchin takes lead in talks with Congress amid internal White House disputes. WASHINGTON-As the coronavirus affects almost every aspect of business, a collection of Trump administration officials-at times at odds with one another-have been seeking to coordinate government action to soften the anticipated blow to the economy.

title: The Day Sports Shut Down
summary: MLB, MLS and the NHL joined the NBA in suspending operations, while the NCAA canceled March Madness. Sports have been the longtime source of comforting distraction through world wars and financial calamity. But games will not play that role in the coronavirus crisis.

title: In a Coronavirus Recession, Corporate Leverage Looks Scarier
summary: Low rates won't do much to help highly-indebted U.S. companies in the developing downturn. Low interest rates make it easier to pay off your loans. But you still need to pay them off.

title: European Stocks Have Worst Day in Decades
summary: European stocks have worst day in decades, with banks at the center of selling. If the European Central Bank's package of measures to counteract the impact of the coronavirus was meant to assuage markets, it appears to have failed miserably.

title: MLB, NHL Suspend Play
summary: The moves come following an emergency meeting of the league's board of governors. Major League Baseball and the National Hockey League both suspended their operations on Thursday because of the coronavirus epidemic sweeping across the U.S., joining the National Basketball Association in what has become a massive shutdown of the American sports scene.

title: Airbnb Bookings Plunge Amid Coronavirus Pandemic
summary: U.S. listings starting to take a hit as big events are canceled. Airbnb Inc.'s bookings are tanking in major cities world-wide amid the coronavirus pandemic, new data show, compounding the pain for the home-sharing giant as it mulls listing in a turbulent market.

title: Coronavirus Lockdown Batters Italy's Fragile Economy
summary: The restrictions on everyday life are the most radical nationwide measures any country has applied to fight the coronavirus epidemic. The Italian economy absorbed another blow on Thursday as the government implemented even stricter measures to stem the spread of the coronavirus in what is the worst outbreak outside of China.

title: Will Christine Lagarde Do Whatever It Takes?
summary: New head of European Central Bank risks repeating mistakes of 2011 eurozone crisis. Perhaps every global crisis is destined to be punctuated by the head of the European Central Bank making a big policy blunder. If so, Christine Lagarde just came very close to hers.

title: Two Democrats, Altered Fortunes, Empty Stands: Dynamics Shift in 11th Debate

title: Meet David Dobrik, Gen Z's Jimmy Fallon
summary: His channel is equal parts 'Jackass' and 'Ellen,' and brands are lining up to work with him. "My big dream is to be a late-night host, but it's like, what does that even mean? And what's that going to mean in four or five years?". David Dobrik thought he'd peaked after he married his best friend's mom. His friend and podcast co-host, Jason Nash, had told him he would never find anyone to marry, and so, as payback, Dobrik became Nash's stepfather. The quickie wedding, conducted at the campy Little White Chapel in Las Vegas, was filmed as an elaborate bit for Dobrik's successful YouTube channel. (Six months later Dobrik instagrammed himself signing divorce papers.) Standing on a fire escape in New York City last May after returning from his honeymoon in Hawaii, the Los Angeles-based YouTuber waved to throngs of screaming fans who had assembled to shop at his pop-up store. As he recalls almost a year later, he turned to his assistant Natalie Mariduena and said, "I think this is it. Like, there's no way I married Jason's mom. Like, what else?"

title: Despite Its Glitz and Glam, The Hamptons Real-Estate Market is Looking Grim

Splitting season-long "share houses" with friends, he noticed that the Hamptons "just kept getting more and more expensive," even as the crowds increased. "You'd go to a coffee shop in Amagansett and wait in line 20 minutes," said Mr. Crowley, now 43, the co-founder of the tech company Foursquare. Eventually, he and his now-wife, Chelsa Crowley, "realized that this isn't our scene," he said.
